awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2 -- Connecting Common Era climate and sea level variability along the Eastern North American coastline
awd_abstract_narration:
Sea level along the eastern North American coastline is rising faster than global sea level and is expected to accelerate dramatically over the 21st century. The uncertainty and societal impact of this acceleration underscores the need for an improved understanding of relationships between regional sea level and climate. High-resolution sea level proxies spanning the past ~2,000 years (the "Common Era") reveal century-scale, decimeter-amplitude (up to ~20-cm), variability along the east coast associated with changes in dynamic sea level (DSL). These changes offer a unique benchmark for climate models, and the closest observational analog for climate-driven sea level change expected in the 21st century. This project will employ statistical and dynamical models to improve the scientific understanding of Common Era sea level changes along the east coast and their relationship with climate. The research team will leverage this knowledge to inform projections of 21st century DSL change and the ability of current-generation climate models to capture those changes, in turn informing coastal resilience efforts along the high-risk eastern North American coast. The project will provide funding and opportunities for an early career scientist and a graduate student to develop a diverse set of skills and collaborators in paleoclimate, climate modeling, and weather and climate risk assessment.

The project team will confront the sparsity of the proxy record and the limitations of current-generation paleoclimate simulations by testing hypotheses about the drivers of sea level variability using a broad statistically- and dynamically-based modeling strategy. Project tasks include: (1) a rigorous assessment of the robustness of regional DSL reconstructions generated with a hierarchical spatio-temporal statistical framework; (2) leveraging the statistical framework to assess linkages between DSL and other climate indices (e.g., North Atlantic Oscillation, Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation, sea surface temperature and salinity, Intertropical Convergence Zone position); and (3) conducting and analyzing coupled climate model simulations. Climate model simulations will be forced by proxy-derived surface fluxes and validated by a synthesis of complementary climate reconstructions. The simulations will reveal the dynamical mechanisms underlying correlations found in reconstructions and demonstrate whether relationships observed in the instrumental record persist over multidecadal-to-centennial timescales. The research is expected to lead to a more complete interpretation of Common Era sea level and climate variability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Along the eastern North American coastline, relative sea level (RSL) is rising faster than global mean sea level and is expected to accelerate dramatically over the 21st century. The uncertainty and societal impact of this acceleration underscores the need for an improved mechanistic understanding of multidecadal-to-centennial relationships between RSL and climate.

 

The instrumental tide-gauge record does not resolve these long timescales, but geological proxies allow RSL records to be extended further back in time. These extended records provide context of sea-level variability and valuable information about the drivers of sea-level change over time and space.

Salt-marsh foraminifera are often used as a sea-level proxy. This project developed a formal way to account for spatial and temporal variability of modern foraminifera and found that foraminiferal-based RSL reconstructions from high marsh environments remain robust and reproducible when incorporating this variability. Using salt-marsh foraminifera as a proxy, this project produced three new relative sea-level reconstructions (two from Newfoundland and one from northern New Jersey).

To compare the new records with existing ones, this project updated a Common Era (last 2000 years) sea-level proxy database. A spatiotemporal statistical model separateed the sea-level signals into global, regional linear, regional non-linear, and local-scale processes to identify spatial patterns and timing of relative sea-level change, as well as contributing processes. Along the eastern North American coastline, three latitudinally-organized groups of sites share coherent regional non-linear trends and indicate that changes in atmospheric/oceanic circulation were likely an important driver of sea-level change in the North Atlantic Ocean during the past 2000 years.

Sea-level budgets at six sites in the northeast U.S provide an understanding of how processes controlling relative sea level have fluctuated through time. Each budget is dominated by regional-scale long-term geological processes of land subsidence over the last 2000 years. Other regional factors, such as ocean dynamics, and local processes specific to each site, such as groundwater withdrawal, contribute much less to each budget and vary through time and by location. The most significant change to the budgets is the increasing global contribution due to ice melt and warming oceans since the 1800s, which becomes equal to the regional geological contribution by the 20th century.

The time of emergence refers to when climatic trends exceed background variability. Using the Common Era sea-level database, this projected identified when modern rates of sea-level rise emerged. It is very likely that rates of global mean sea-level rise emerged above pre-industrial rates by 1863 CE, which is similar in timing to evidence for early ocean warming and glacier melt. At individual sites within the North Atlantic, the time of emergence reveals a distinct spatial pattern, appearing earliest in the mid-Atlantic region (1863-1894 CE) and later in Canada and Europe (1930-1964 CE). Regional and local sea-level changes occurring over different time periods drive the spatial pattern in emergence, suggesting regional processes underlie centennial-timescale sea-level variability over the Common Era. The analysis also further demonstrated the significant increase in rates of relative sea-level rise since the 1800s compared to the last 3000 years, confirming with virtual certainty that the 20th century saw faster global mean sea-level rise than any century since 1000 BCE.
